{"ops":[{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"This runbook will check the configurations of multicast source tree in four steps."},{"insert":"

"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"1. Checking the current state of multicast source tree, status of the neighbors and the forwarding paths of the multicast traffic."},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"2. Checking all the current multicast configurations."},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"3. Checking PIM DM state refresh status."},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"4. Checking the reachability of the destination multicast address by sending the ICMP traffic (ping) if the problem can be located and resolved via the above 3 steps."},{"insert":"

"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"References:"},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial","link":"http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipmulti_optim/configuration/xe-16/imc-optim-xe-16-book/imc-pim-rfrsh.html"},"insert":"Understanding and Troubleshooting PIM dense mode Problems"},{"insert":"
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
This runbook will check the configurations of multicast source tree in four steps.

1. Checking the current state of multicast source tree, status of the neighbors and the forwarding paths of the multicast traffic.
2. Checking all the current multicast configurations.
3. Checking PIM DM state refresh status.
4. Checking the reachability of the destination multicast address by sending the ICMP traffic (ping) if the problem can be located and resolved via the above 3 steps.

References:
Understanding and Troubleshooting PIM dense mode Problems

{"ops":[{"insert":"Use this App to analyze configuration and performance of multicasting, including PIM neighbor count, receiver count, packets forwarded/received, and more.

"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Input:"},{"insert":"
Source "},{"attributes":{"color":"#888888"},"insert":"(Example: 216.218.254.202)"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"Group "},{"attributes":{"color":"#888888"},"insert":"(Example: 224.1.1.1)"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Output:"},{"insert":"
		Data unit items on device level:
			1) PIM neighbor count
			2) Receiver count
			3) Rate (including pps and kbps)
			4) Packets forwarded/received
			5) RPF failed packet count

		Data unit items on interface level:
			1) Packets in/out
			2) PIM neighbor count
			3) IGMP joins and leaves count

		Highlight items on device level:
			1) Multicast Tree Hops
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
Use this App to analyze configuration and performance of multicasting, including PIM neighbor count, receiver count, packets forwarded/received, and more.

Input:
Source (Example: 216.218.254.202)
Group (Example: 224.1.1.1)

Output:
		Data unit items on device level:
			1) PIM neighbor count
			2) Receiver count
			3) Rate (including pps and kbps)
			4) Packets forwarded/received
			5) RPF failed packet count

		Data unit items on interface level:
			1) Packets in/out
			2) PIM neighbor count
			3) IGMP joins and leaves count

		Highlight items on device level:
			1) Multicast Tree Hops

rb_notes.text:
Monitoring Multicast Distribution Tree

This Qapp is designed for checking the configuration of multicast and analyzing the performance of it. Various statistics will be collected from your environment.

Device Level Statistics:
PIM neighbor
Receiver
Transmission Rate (packets per second (pps) and kilobits per second (kbp)) 
Packets forwarded/received
Multicast Reverse Path Forwarding (RPF) failure

Interface Level:
Packets input / output
PIM neighbor
IGMP join / leave event

Required Inputs (from user) :
Multicast source IP address 
Multicast destination IP address

rb_notes.text:
Highlighting Multicast Source Tree

Mapping the hops of multicast source tree and highlighting the multicast roles and configurations on the Qmap.

Required Inputs (from user) :
	Please select a Qmap or a shared device group.

Outputs:
	A Qmap which contains the hops of multicast source tree. The roles (FHR, LHR and reporter) and configurations will be highlighted.

Related Commands:
	The output from the following commands:
	1) Cisco Router, Cisco IOS Switch:
show ip mroute
show ip igmp groups

rb_notes.text:
This runbook will check the configurations of multicast source tree in four steps.

1. Checking the current state of multicast source tree, status of the neighbors and the forwarding paths of the multicast traffic.
2. Checking all the current multicast configurations.
3. Checking PIM DM state refresh status.
4. Checking the reachability of the destination multicast address by sending the ICMP traffic (ping) if the problem can be located and resolved via the above 3 steps.

References:
Understanding and Troubleshooting PIM dense mode Problems

Checking the reachability of the destination multicast address

Related Commands:
		The output from the following commands:
			1) ping {destination multicast IP address}

rb_notes.text:
Description 
Following are the PIM Dense Mode State Refresh control messages that are sent and received by a PIM router after the debug ip pim privileged EXEC command is configured for multicast group 239.0.0.1:

Router# debug ip pim 239.0.0.1
*Mar 1 00:25:10.416:PIM:Originating refresh message for
(172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
*Mar 1 00:25:10.416:PIM:Send SR on GigabitEthernet1/1/0 for (172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
TTL=9
The following output from the show ip mroute command displays are the resulting prune timer changes for GigabitEthernet interface1/0/0 and multicast group 239.0.0.1. (The following output assumes that the debug ip pim privileged EXEC command has already been configured on the router.) In the first output from the show ip mroute command, the prune timer reads 00:02:06. The debug messages indicate that a PIM Dense Mode State Refresh control message is received and sent on Ethernet interface 1/0, and that other PIM Dense Mode State Refresh routers were discovered. In the second output from the show ip mroute command, the prune timer has been reset to 00:02:55.
Router# show ip mroute 239.0.0.1
(172.16.8.3, 239.0.0.1), 00:09:50/00:02:06, flags:PT
 Incoming interface:GigabitEthernet1/1/0, RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
 Outgoing interface list:
 GigabitEthernet1/0/0, Prune/Dense, 00:09:43/00:02:06
Router#
*Mar 1 00:32:06.657:PIM:SR on iif from 172.16.5.2 orig 172.16.8.1 for
(172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:    flags:prune-indicator 
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Cached metric is [0/0]
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Keep RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Send SR on Ethernet1/0 for (172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
TTL=8
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:    flags:prune-indicator 
Router# show ip mroute 239.0.0.1
(172.16.8.3, 239.0.0.1), 00:10:01/00:02:55, flags:PT
 Incoming interface:GigabitEthernet1/1/0, RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
 Outgoing interface list:
 GigabitEthernet1/0/0, Prune/Dense, 00:09:55/00:02:55

rb_notes.text:
Monitoring Multicast Distribution Tree

This Qapp is designed for checking the configuration of multicast and analyzing the performance of it. Various statistics will be collected from your environment.

Device Level Statistics:
PIM neighbor
Receiver
Transmission Rate (packets per second (pps) and kilobits per second (kbp)) 
Packets forwarded/received
Multicast Reverse Path Forwarding (RPF) failure

Interface Level:
Packets input / output
PIM neighbor
IGMP join / leave event

Required Inputs (from user) :
Multicast source IP address 
Multicast destination IP address

rb_notes.text:
Description 
Following are the PIM Dense Mode State Refresh control messages that are sent and received by a PIM router after the debug ip pim privileged EXEC command is configured for multicast group 239.0.0.1:

Router# debug ip pim 239.0.0.1
*Mar 1 00:25:10.416:PIM:Originating refresh message for
(172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
*Mar 1 00:25:10.416:PIM:Send SR on GigabitEthernet1/1/0 for (172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
TTL=9
The following output from the show ip mroute command displays are the resulting prune timer changes for GigabitEthernet interface1/0/0 and multicast group 239.0.0.1. (The following output assumes that the debug ip pim privileged EXEC command has already been configured on the router.) In the first output from the show ip mroute command, the prune timer reads 00:02:06. The debug messages indicate that a PIM Dense Mode State Refresh control message is received and sent on Ethernet interface 1/0, and that other PIM Dense Mode State Refresh routers were discovered. In the second output from the show ip mroute command, the prune timer has been reset to 00:02:55.
Router# show ip mroute 239.0.0.1
(172.16.8.3, 239.0.0.1), 00:09:50/00:02:06, flags:PT
 Incoming interface:GigabitEthernet1/1/0, RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
 Outgoing interface list:
 GigabitEthernet1/0/0, Prune/Dense, 00:09:43/00:02:06
Router#
*Mar 1 00:32:06.657:PIM:SR on iif from 172.16.5.2 orig 172.16.8.1 for
(172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:    flags:prune-indicator 
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Cached metric is [0/0]
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Keep RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Send SR on Ethernet1/0 for (172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
TTL=8
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:    flags:prune-indicator 
Router# show ip mroute 239.0.0.1
(172.16.8.3, 239.0.0.1), 00:10:01/00:02:55, flags:PT
 Incoming interface:GigabitEthernet1/1/0, RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
 Outgoing interface list:
 GigabitEthernet1/0/0, Prune/Dense, 00:09:55/00:02:55

rb_notes.text:
Highlighting Multicast Source Tree

Mapping the hops of multicast source tree and highlighting the multicast roles and configurations on the Qmap.

Required Inputs (from user) :
	Please select a Qmap or a shared device group.

Outputs:
	A Qmap which contains the hops of multicast source tree. The roles (FHR, LHR and reporter) and configurations will be highlighted.

Related Commands:
	The output from the following commands:
	1) Cisco Router, Cisco IOS Switch:
show ip mroute
show ip igmp groups
<Configuration>

{"ops":[{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"This runbook will check the configurations of multicast source tree in four steps."},{"insert":"

"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"1. Checking the current state of multicast source tree, status of the neighbors and the forwarding paths of the multicast traffic."},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"2. Checking all the current multicast configurations."},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"3. Checking PIM DM state refresh status."},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"4. Checking the reachability of the destination multicast address by sending the ICMP traffic (ping) if the problem can be located and resolved via the above 3 steps."},{"insert":"

"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"References:"},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial","link":"http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipmulti_optim/configuration/xe-16/imc-optim-xe-16-book/imc-pim-rfrsh.html"},"insert":"Understanding and Troubleshooting PIM dense mode Problems"},{"insert":"
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
This runbook will check the configurations of multicast source tree in four steps.

1. Checking the current state of multicast source tree, status of the neighbors and the forwarding paths of the multicast traffic.
2. Checking all the current multicast configurations.
3. Checking PIM DM state refresh status.
4. Checking the reachability of the destination multicast address by sending the ICMP traffic (ping) if the problem can be located and resolved via the above 3 steps.

References:
Understanding and Troubleshooting PIM dense mode Problems

{"ops":[{"insert":"Use this App to analyze configuration and performance of multicasting, including PIM neighbor count, receiver count, packets forwarded/received, and more.

"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Input:"},{"insert":"
Source "},{"attributes":{"color":"#888888"},"insert":"(Example: 216.218.254.202)"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"Group "},{"attributes":{"color":"#888888"},"insert":"(Example: 224.1.1.1)"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Output:"},{"insert":"
		Data unit items on device level:
			1) PIM neighbor count
			2) Receiver count
			3) Rate (including pps and kbps)
			4) Packets forwarded/received
			5) RPF failed packet count

		Data unit items on interface level:
			1) Packets in/out
			2) PIM neighbor count
			3) IGMP joins and leaves count

		Highlight items on device level:
			1) Multicast Tree Hops
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
Use this App to analyze configuration and performance of multicasting, including PIM neighbor count, receiver count, packets forwarded/received, and more.

Input:
Source (Example: 216.218.254.202)
Group (Example: 224.1.1.1)

Output:
		Data unit items on device level:
			1) PIM neighbor count
			2) Receiver count
			3) Rate (including pps and kbps)
			4) Packets forwarded/received
			5) RPF failed packet count

		Data unit items on interface level:
			1) Packets in/out
			2) PIM neighbor count
			3) IGMP joins and leaves count

		Highlight items on device level:
			1) Multicast Tree Hops

rb_notes.text:
Description 
Following are the PIM Dense Mode State Refresh control messages that are sent and received by a PIM router after the debug ip pim privileged EXEC command is configured for multicast group 239.0.0.1:

Router# debug ip pim 239.0.0.1
*Mar 1 00:25:10.416:PIM:Originating refresh message for
(172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
*Mar 1 00:25:10.416:PIM:Send SR on GigabitEthernet1/1/0 for (172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
TTL=9
The following output from the show ip mroute command displays are the resulting prune timer changes for GigabitEthernet interface1/0/0 and multicast group 239.0.0.1. (The following output assumes that the debug ip pim privileged EXEC command has already been configured on the router.) In the first output from the show ip mroute command, the prune timer reads 00:02:06. The debug messages indicate that a PIM Dense Mode State Refresh control message is received and sent on Ethernet interface 1/0, and that other PIM Dense Mode State Refresh routers were discovered. In the second output from the show ip mroute command, the prune timer has been reset to 00:02:55.
Router# show ip mroute 239.0.0.1
(172.16.8.3, 239.0.0.1), 00:09:50/00:02:06, flags:PT
 Incoming interface:GigabitEthernet1/1/0, RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
 Outgoing interface list:
 GigabitEthernet1/0/0, Prune/Dense, 00:09:43/00:02:06
Router#
*Mar 1 00:32:06.657:PIM:SR on iif from 172.16.5.2 orig 172.16.8.1 for
(172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:    flags:prune-indicator 
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Cached metric is [0/0]
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Keep RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Send SR on Ethernet1/0 for (172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
TTL=8
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:    flags:prune-indicator 
Router# show ip mroute 239.0.0.1
(172.16.8.3, 239.0.0.1), 00:10:01/00:02:55, flags:PT
 Incoming interface:GigabitEthernet1/1/0, RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
 Outgoing interface list:
 GigabitEthernet1/0/0, Prune/Dense, 00:09:55/00:02:55

rb_notes.text:
Highlighting Multicast Source Tree

Mapping the hops of multicast source tree and highlighting the multicast roles and configurations on the Qmap.

Required Inputs (from user) :
	Please select a Qmap or a shared device group.

Outputs:
	A Qmap which contains the hops of multicast source tree. The roles (FHR, LHR and reporter) and configurations will be highlighted.

Related Commands:
	The output from the following commands:
	1) Cisco Router, Cisco IOS Switch:
show ip mroute
show ip igmp groups
<Configuration>

{"ops":[{"insert":"Use this App to analyze configuration and performance of multicasting, including PIM neighbor count, receiver count, packets forwarded/received, and more.

"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Input:"},{"insert":"
Source "},{"attributes":{"color":"#888888"},"insert":"(Example: 216.218.254.202)"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"Group "},{"attributes":{"color":"#888888"},"insert":"(Example: 224.1.1.1)"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Output:"},{"insert":"
		Data unit items on device level:
			1) PIM neighbor count
			2) Receiver count
			3) Rate (including pps and kbps)
			4) Packets forwarded/received
			5) RPF failed packet count

		Data unit items on interface level:
			1) Packets in/out
			2) PIM neighbor count
			3) IGMP joins and leaves count

		Highlight items on device level:
			1) Multicast Tree Hops
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
Use this App to analyze configuration and performance of multicasting, including PIM neighbor count, receiver count, packets forwarded/received, and more.

Input:
Source (Example: 216.218.254.202)
Group (Example: 224.1.1.1)

Output:
		Data unit items on device level:
			1) PIM neighbor count
			2) Receiver count
			3) Rate (including pps and kbps)
			4) Packets forwarded/received
			5) RPF failed packet count

		Data unit items on interface level:
			1) Packets in/out
			2) PIM neighbor count
			3) IGMP joins and leaves count

		Highlight items on device level:
			1) Multicast Tree Hops

rb_notes.text:
Monitoring Multicast Distribution Tree

This Qapp is designed for checking the configuration of multicast and analyzing the performance of it. Various statistics will be collected from your environment.

Device Level Statistics:
PIM neighbor
Receiver
Transmission Rate (packets per second (pps) and kilobits per second (kbp)) 
Packets forwarded/received
Multicast Reverse Path Forwarding (RPF) failure

Interface Level:
Packets input / output
PIM neighbor
IGMP join / leave event

Required Inputs (from user) :
Multicast source IP address 
Multicast destination IP address

rb_notes.text:
Description 
Following are the PIM Dense Mode State Refresh control messages that are sent and received by a PIM router after the debug ip pim privileged EXEC command is configured for multicast group 239.0.0.1:

Router# debug ip pim 239.0.0.1
*Mar 1 00:25:10.416:PIM:Originating refresh message for
(172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
*Mar 1 00:25:10.416:PIM:Send SR on GigabitEthernet1/1/0 for (172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
TTL=9
The following output from the show ip mroute command displays are the resulting prune timer changes for GigabitEthernet interface1/0/0 and multicast group 239.0.0.1. (The following output assumes that the debug ip pim privileged EXEC command has already been configured on the router.) In the first output from the show ip mroute command, the prune timer reads 00:02:06. The debug messages indicate that a PIM Dense Mode State Refresh control message is received and sent on Ethernet interface 1/0, and that other PIM Dense Mode State Refresh routers were discovered. In the second output from the show ip mroute command, the prune timer has been reset to 00:02:55.
Router# show ip mroute 239.0.0.1
(172.16.8.3, 239.0.0.1), 00:09:50/00:02:06, flags:PT
 Incoming interface:GigabitEthernet1/1/0, RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
 Outgoing interface list:
 GigabitEthernet1/0/0, Prune/Dense, 00:09:43/00:02:06
Router#
*Mar 1 00:32:06.657:PIM:SR on iif from 172.16.5.2 orig 172.16.8.1 for
(172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:    flags:prune-indicator 
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Cached metric is [0/0]
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Keep RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:PIM:Send SR on Ethernet1/0 for (172.16.8.3,239.0.0.1)
TTL=8
*Mar 1 00:32:06.661:    flags:prune-indicator 
Router# show ip mroute 239.0.0.1
(172.16.8.3, 239.0.0.1), 00:10:01/00:02:55, flags:PT
 Incoming interface:GigabitEthernet1/1/0, RPF nbr 172.16.5.2
 Outgoing interface list:
 GigabitEthernet1/0/0, Prune/Dense, 00:09:55/00:02:55

"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial"},"insert":"3. Checking PIM DM state refresh status."},{"insert":"

"},{"attributes":{"font":"arial","link":"http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipmulti_optim/configuration/xe-16/imc-optim-xe-16-book/imc-pim-rfrsh.html"},"insert":"Understanding and Troubleshooting PIM dense mode Problems"},{"insert":"
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
This runbook will check the configurations of multicast source tree in four steps.

1. Checking the current state of multicast source tree, status of the neighbors and the forwarding paths of the multicast traffic.
2. Checking all the current multicast configurations.
3. Checking PIM DM state refresh status.
4. Checking the reachability of the destination multicast address by sending the ICMP traffic (ping) if the problem can be located and resolved via the above 3 steps.

References:
Understanding and Troubleshooting PIM dense mode Problems
